name: (2Z)-2-(1,3-Benzothiazol-2-yl)-3-(2-methoxyphenyl)acrylonitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-599

name: (2Z)-2-(1,3-Benzothiazol-2-yl)-3-(2-methoxyphenyl)acrylonitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-599
Reason: To predict the melting point of (2Z)-2-(1,3-Benzothiazol-2-yl)-3-(2-methoxyphenyl)acrylonitrile, we will consider the effects of various functional groups and structural features on the basic scaffold, which is benzene known to have a melting point of 5.5 °C. The presence of the 1,3-benzothiazole increases the melting point due to the addition of nitrogen and sulfur heteroatoms, which promote stronger intermolecular forces (+50-60 °C). The acrylonitrile group introduces electron-withdrawing cyano (-C#N) and alkenyl groups which can increase the rigidity of the molecule (+20-30 °C). Methoxyphenyl (2-methoxyphenyl) group is an electron-donating and bulky group which also increases the melting point (+10-15 °C). From these considerations, we estimate an increase of +80-105 °C above the base benzene melting point.

name: (2Z)-2-(1,3-Benzothiazol-2-yl)-3-(2-methoxyphenyl)acrylonitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-599
Reason: To predict the melting point of (2Z)-2-(1,3-Benzothiazol-2-yl)-3-(2-methoxyphenyl)acrylonitrile, we have to analyze the effect of each functional group present in the molecule based on the basic benzene structure, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The 1,3-benzothiazole ring introduces a nitrogen and sulfur, which generally contribute to stronger intermolecular forces due to their ability to participate in hydrogen bonding and dipole interactions, potentially increasing the melting point by approximately +50-60 °C. The acrylonitrile group contains a cyano (-C#N) group which is strongly electronegative and can create dipole-dipole interactions, plus an alkenyl group which makes the molecule more rigid, both effects potentially contributing to an increase of about +20-30 °C. The methoxyphenyl group is an electron-donating and bulky group, providing steric hindrance and additional pi-pi interactions that can further enhance the melting point by an estimated +10-15 °C. When these effects are combined, we predict an overall increase of +80-105 °C above the base benzene melting point.

name: (2Z)-2-(1,3-Benzothiazol-2-yl)-3-(2-methoxyphenyl)acrylonitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-599
Reason: The compound (2Z)-2-(1,3-Benzothiazol-2-yl)-3-(2-methoxyphenyl)acrylonitrile is composed of several functional groups that influence its melting point. The base structure to consider might be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. There are several substituents in the molecule that will affect the melting point: 1. Benzothiazole ring: This fused heterocyclic compound will significantly increase the melting point due to the presence of nitrogen and sulfur atoms, which increase intermolecular forces (+50°C). 2. Phenyl ring: Generally, each additional phenyl ring in a molecule increases the melting point due to increased pi-pi stacking and van der Waals forces (+50°C). 3. Nitrile group (-C#N): This group is capable of dipole-dipole interactions and may raise the melting point (+30°C). 4. Methoxy group (-OCH3): This group can form weak dipole-dipole and hydrogen bonding interactions, slightly raising the melting point (+5°C). 5. Acrylonitrile moiety (-CH=CH-C#N): The conjugated system can also increase the melting point due to additional pi-pi interactions and planarity of the molecule (+15°C). Adding all these contributions to the base melting point of benzene, we get an estimated melting point for the target compound.
